questions.text: What is the population covered by Municipal Boards?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) 10,000-2,00,000

Explanation:

Municipal board operates in urban areas and covers a population of 10,000-2,00,000.

Municipal Board:

Aspect

Details

Head

Chairman or President, elected by members of the Municipal Board.

Term

Typically 3 to 5 years.

Functions
  • Construction and maintenance of roads, bridges, and public infrastructure.
  • Sanitation and drainage systems.
  • Street lighting.
  • Water supply.
  • Maintenance of hospitals and dispensaries.
  • Education.
  • Civil registration (births and deaths).

Administration
  • Executive Agency: This includes the Commissioner, Secretary, Engineer, and Health Officer.
  • Councillors: Elected from different wards of the city.

​

questions.text: The logo shown above represents a health scheme launched by the Government of India. What is the primary objective of this program?

choices.text: To provide comprehensive outbreak response essential drugs and diagnostic services.
To offer health insurance coverage to the economically disadvantaged
To reduce morbidity due to vaccine-preventable diseases in children
To promote accessible, affordable, and quality healthcare to the rural population

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) To offer health insurance coverage to the economically disadvantaged

Explanation:

The logo represents Ayushman Bharat-Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PMJAY), a scheme of the Government of India designed to provide health insurance coverage to economically disadvantaged families.

 

Ayushman Bharat - Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PMJAY):

  • An initiative launched in 2018 by Govt. of India to achieve UHC
  • Provides all the elements, including NCDS, in primary care.
  • Benefits:
    • Coverage: up to INR 5 lakh per family per year for secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.
    • There is no restriction on the number of family members.
    • Cashless access across the country
    • All pre-existing conditions covered
    • Covers the cost of treatment, up to 3 days of pre-hospitalization and 15 days of post-hospitalization follow-up care.
  • Beneficiaries: Vulnerable and poor populations based on the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) database.

Option A: Health and Wellness Centre, established under the National Health Policy in 2017, offers comprehensive health care, including maternal and child health, communicable disease, and non-communicable disease services, as well as free essential medications and diagnostics.

Option C: Mission Indradhanush aims to achieve more than 90% full immunization coverage and reduce child mortality and morbidity due to vaccine-preventable diseases.

Option D: The National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) provides accessible, affordable, and quality healthcare to the rural population, reducing mortality rates and disease transmission.

questions.text: A 30-year-old laborer struggles to access basic healthcare services due to high costs and limited availability. The logo shown below represents an initiative that aims to address issues like the one faced by this patient. Which healthcare concept does this logo represent?

choices.text: National Program for Prevention and Control of cancer and diabetes

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Universal Health Coverage

Explanation:

The logo represents Universal Health Coverage (UHC) ensuring that all individuals receive health services without suffering financial hardship.

Universal Health Coverage:

  • 12th December: International Universal Health Coverage Day given by the United States.
  • Includes a full range of essential health services, from health promotion to prevention, treatment, rehabilitation, and palliative care.
  • Includes non-communicable diseases (NCDS) and AYUSH.
  • Includes financial protection: Insurance coverage.
  • Global program with the key target of the UN Sustainable Development.
  • Goals, aiming to achieve UHC by 2030.
  • Aims:
    • Equity in access (Everywhere, everyone who needs services should get them).
    • Good quality and affordable health service.
    • Protection against financial risk (without having to bear financial hardship).

 

The Accessible India Campaign (Sugamya Bharat Abhiyan) was launched to create a barrier-free and favorable environment for universal accessibility to people with disabilities.

The Integrated Disease Surveillance Project (IDSP) is designed to improve disease surveillance and response to outbreaks.

The National Programme for Prevention and Control of Non-Communicable Diseases (NPCDCS) aims to tackle non-communicable diseases (NCDs) through prevention, early diagnosis, and management.

questions.text: Which primary healthcare principle is represented by the displayed image to ensure appropriate usability and quality?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Appropriate Technology

Explanation:

The usage of Vaccine Vial Monitors (VVMs) to ensure vaccine usability and quality falls under the pillar of appropriate technology in primary healthcare.

Four Pillars of Primary Health Care:

Equitable distribution (Option D):
  • Equitable distribution of health services irrespective of their socio-economic status.

Intersectoral coordination (Option C):
  • Involves collaboration from other sectors like agriculture, education, etc.
  • Maintains good health.

Appropriate technology (Option A):
  • Use of technology that is accessible, affordable, and suitable for the community
  • Eg:
    • ORS
    • VVM (Vaccine Vial Monitor): Heat sensitive label
    • Shakir tape: Malnutrition grading
    • Kangaroo mother care: Preterm care

Community participation (Option B):
  • Ensure the participation of the community in planning, implementing and maintaining.
  • For the promotion and maintenance of their health.
  • Eg: ASHA workers are residents of the same community.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding elements of primary healthcare are true:

1. It includes education concerning health problems and methods of preventing them.

2. It involves the promotion of food supply and appropriate nutrition.

3. It provides essential and non-essential drugs.

4. It consists of individuals who have a common health goal based on community requirements.

5. It emphasizes maternal and child health care, including family planning.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) 1,2, and 5

Explanation:

Elements or Components of Primary Health Care according to ‘Declaration of Alma Ata’in Kazakhistan:

Mnemonic: ELEMENTS

  • Essential medicines (especially paracetamol) (Statement 3)
  • Locally endemic diseases -Prevention and Control
  • Health Education (Statement 1)
  • Maternal, child health and family planning (Statement 5)
  • EPI (Expanded Immunization Programme) now changed to UIP (Universal Immunization Programme)
  • Nutrition and food supply (Statement 2)
  • Treatment of common ailments
  • Safe water supply and sanitation

Note: A health team is defined as a group of people sharing a common health goal and objectives, determined by community needs and towards the achievement of which each member contributes with her or his competence and respects the functions of the other. (Statement 4)

questions.text: Which of the following does not come under the 4 A's of primary healthcare?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Accountability

Explanation:

Accountability, which relates to the responsibility of healthcare providers to deliver quality care, is not listed among the 4 A's of primary healthcare.

Health for All:

  • Proposed in 1977 by the World Health Assembly.
  • Attainment of the level of health by all individuals enabling them to lead socially and economically productive lives.
  • The 4 A's of primary healthcare are:

Accessibility: Healthcare services are available and reachable by all. (Option A)

Affordability: Healthcare services are economically viable for all (Option B)

Acceptability: Healthcare services are culturally and socially appropriate (Option D)

Availability: Appropriate ratio between the population of an administrative unit and the health facility

Principles of primary health care: 

  • Appropriate technology
  • Community participation
  • Equitable distribution
  • Inter-sectoral coordination

questions.text: How many tests are available in Primary Health Centers under the Free Drugs and Diagnostic Service Initiative of the National Health Mission?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A)19

Explanation:

Under the Free Drugs and Diagnostic Service Initiative of the National Health Mission:

  • Primary Health Centers: 19 free tests.
  • Community Health Centres: 39 free tests.
  • District hospitals: 6 free tests.

questions.text: What should be the minimum number of members in the Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) 15

Explanation:

Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee-VHSNC:

Aspect

Details

Formation

Formed at the revenue village level

Composition

There are at least 15 members, including elected Panchayat members (committee leaders), health workers, community members/beneficiaries, and representatives from vulnerable sections and hamlets.

Member Secretary

ASHA (also the convener of VHSNC).

Roles and Responsibilities
  • Create awareness and conduct surveys about nutritional issues and deficiencies.
  • Identify local nutritious foods and include them in the Village Health Plan.
  • Monitor Village Health and Nutrition Day.
  • Facilitate referral to Nutritional Rehabilitation Centre (NRC).
  • Supervise Anganwadi Centre (AWC).
  • Act as grievances redressal forum on health and nutrition.

Relationship with Gram Panchayat

Acts as a sub-committee under the overall supervision of Gram Panchayat.

questions.text: What is the role of Rogi Kalyan Samiti?

choices.text: Support the functioning of health facilities

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Support the functioning of health facilities

Explanation:

Rogi Kalyan Samiti:

Aspect

Details

Synonyms
  • Patient Welfare Committee
  • Hospital Management Society

Purpose

Manage hospital affairs, ensure patient welfare, and improve facilities in hospitals.

Structure

Registered society with community members as trustees.

Financial Assistance

Provided through untied funds for activities related to patient welfare.

Responsibilities
  • Upkeep of hospital facilities.
  • Ensuring the provision of better facilities to patients.
  • Financial management and accountability.
  • Community engagement and participation.

Location

It is found in almost all DHs, SDHs, CHCs, and PHCs across India.

questions.text: According to the national health policy, how many people should have one health subcenter (HSC) in hilly and tribal areas?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) 3000

Explanation:

As per the national health policy,

Type of health sub-centre

Plain population

Hilly/tribal/desert population

Rural HSC

1 per 5000

1 per 3000

Urban HSC

1 per 15,000-20,000

-
Categorisations

Type A: No delivery

Type B: Delivery happens

 

  

Urban PHC is called Swasthya Chowki
Subcenter and PHC together form Health and wellness clinic

questions.text: Which committee established the Panchayati Raj Institution?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A)Balwant Rai Mehta Committee.

Explanation:

The Panchayati Raj Institution was established by the Balwant Rai Mehta Committee.

Panchayati Raj:

  • 3-tier structure of rural self-government.
  • Links village to district.

Panchayati Raj Institutions:

  • Panchayat- at the village level.
  • Panchayat samiti- at block level.
  • Zilla parishad - at the district level.

Level

Institution

Description and Functions

Village

Gram Sabha

Assembly of all adults in the village; discusses local issues; elects members of Gram Panchayat.

Gram Panchayat

The executive body of Gram Sabha; plans and executes local development activities, led by a President (Sarpanch).

Nyaya Panchayat

Deals with local disputes and minor offences; provides justice at the village level.

Block

Panchayat Samiti

Consists of Sarpanchas (heads) of village Panchayats, MLAs, MPs, and others; implements community development.

Block Development Officer (BDO)

Secretary of Panchayat Samiti; provides technical guidance for development projects.

District

Zilla Parishad

Represents Panchayat Samitis, MLAs, MPs, and others; supervises and coordinates development activities at the district level.

District Administration

Includes administrative officers (e.g., District Collector) responsible for overall governance.

questions.text: Which among the following is NOT a function of Mahila Arogya Samiti?

choices.text: Focus on preventive and promotive care
Act as a peer education group
Providing primary medical care for minor ailments of women

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: D) Providing primary medical care for minor ailments of women

EXPLANATION:

Mahila aryogya samiti is establised under National Urban Health Mission-NUHM

Its functions are -

  • Focus on preventive and promotive care
  • Act as a peer education group
  • Facilitate access to identified facilities
  • Community monitoring and referral
  • Risk pooling fund and health insurance

questions.text: An ASHA worker ensures institutional delivery of a mother from her village. How much incentive does she get regularly?

choices.text: Depending on the tasks ASHA completes

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: D)Depending on the tasks ASHA completes

EXPLANATION:

ASHA is NOT entitled to any regular incentive.

However, under various schemes, she receives task-based incentives.

Area

Task

Incentive

Reproductive health

Ensuring antenatal care and institutional delivery

Rural-300

Urban-200

Delaying birth of first child by 2 years after marriage

500

Ensuring spacing of 3 years after first child

500

Accompanying for IUCD insertion

150

Home visit for newborn and postpartum mother

250
 

TB

DOTS provider for new cases

1000

DOTS provider for previously treated cases

1500

Treatment and support for drug-resistant TB cases

5000

Leprosy

Refers and follows a paucibacillary leprosy case throughout the treatment course

650

Refers and follows a multibacillary leprosy case throughout the treatment course

850

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an ASHA role?

choices.text: Providing counseling on birth preparedness and safe delivery
Administering vaccines to infants and children
Mobilizing the community for health awareness programs
Providing directly observed treatment short-course (DOTS) for tuberculosis

questions.solution:
CORRECT ANSWER: B) Administering vaccines to infants and children 

Explanation:

Roles of ASHA:

  • Educating on health determinants
  • Counseling women on birth preparedness, safe delivery, breastfeeding, immunization, contraception, and prevention of infection
  • Mobilizing the community to access health services
  • Working with village health and sanitation committees
  • Escorting pregnant women and children to health facilities
  • Providing primary medical care for minor ailments and first aid
  • Providing DOTS
  • Acting as a depot holder for essential provisions and drug kits
  • Reporting births, deaths, and health issues to health centres
  • Promoting the construction of household toilets

questions.text: Which statements about an Accredited Social Health Activist-ASHA is true?

choices.text: Can be a male or female

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Preferably from the age group 25-45

Explanation:

ASHA should be:

  • A resident of the same village
  • A married/divorced/widow
  • Preferably from the age group 25-45
  • Educated up to class 10
  • One ASHA for 1000 population/per habitation

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary function of a Female Health Worker (auxiliary Nurse Midwife - ANM)?

choices.text: Registering and providing care to pregnant women

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Registering and providing care to pregnant women

Explanation:

Duty Area

Health Worker Male (HWM)

Health Worker Female (ANM)

Maternal and Child Health

  
  • Register and provide care to pregnant women
  • Conduct deliveries
  • Postnatal home visits
  • Educate on breastfeeding

Family Planning
  • Distribute contraceptives
  • Follow-up with acceptors
  • Maintain eligible couple registers
  • Distribute contraceptives
  • Family planning education

Immunisation
  • Administer vaccines
  • Immunise pregnant women and children
  • Cold chain maintenance

Communicable Diseases

Treat minor ailment

Disease education and prevention

Nutrition
  • Identify malnutrition cases
  • Provide treatment, advice, and referral
  • Distribute supplements
  • Monitor growth and development
  • Identify malnutrition cases
  • Provide treatment, advice, and referral

Record Keeping
  • Maintain health records
  • Submit reports
  • Manage health records
  • Submit reports

Environmental Health
  • Chlorinate water sources
  • Educate on sanitation
  • Maintain cleanliness and medical waste disposal

Community Education
  • Health education on specific diseases
  • Conduct health education sessions

Specific Programme Responsibilities
  • National vector-borne disease control programme
  • Malaria slide preparation- every 15 days
  • Leprosy eradication programme
  • RNTCP
  • National blindness control programme
  • Expanded programme on immunisation.
  • Reproductive and child health programme
  • Universal Programme on Immunization-UIP

questions.text: All of the following are true about a primary health centre (PHC) except?

choices.text: The presence of an AYUSH officer is not essential
At least 2 staff nurses per PHC should be present
The recommended bed count is at least 6 per PHC

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Type A PHC: delivery load <15

 

Explanation:

  • Type A PHC: delivery load < 20

Standards per PHC:

Staffing count
  • Type A: 13-18
  • Type B: 14-21

Staffing division
  • Essential: 1 medical officer, 2 nurses, 1 pharmacist, 1 health worker male & 1 health worker female, 1 lab technician (Option C)
  • Desirable: 1 AYUSH officer (Option A)

Categorization
  • Type A: <20 deliveries (Option B)
  • Type B: >20 deliveries

Bed count
  • Six (Option D)

Services
  • 24*7 emergency services
  • Minimum 6 hours of outpatient service
  • Antenatal, perinatal (normal delivery & cesarean section) and postnatal services
  • MTP & contraception
  • Neonatal & infant care
  • Pediatric care: pneumonia, diarrhea, SAM
  • Communicable & non-communicable diseases services
